title: 2012 United States presidential election in Vermont
text:
The 2012 United States presidential election in Vermont took place on November 6, 2012, as part of the <a href="2012%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">2012 United States presidential election</a> in which all 50 states plus the <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">District of Columbia</a> participated. <a href="Vermont">Vermont</a> voters chose three electors to represent them in the <a href="United%20States%20Electoral%20College">Electoral College</a> via a popular vote pitting <a href="incumbent">incumbent</a> <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic</a> <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President</a> <a href="Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama</a> and his running mate, <a href="Vice%20President%20of%20the%20United%20States">Vice President</a> <a href="Joe%20Biden">Joe Biden</a>, against <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> challenger and former <a href="Governor%20of%20Massachusetts">Massachusetts Governor</a> <a href="Mitt%20Romney">Mitt Romney</a> and his running mate, <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives">Congressman</a> <a href="Paul%20Ryan">Paul Ryan</a>.
A very <a href="Liberalism%20in%20the%20United%20States">liberal</a> <a href="Northeastern%20United%20States">Northeastern</a> state, and a former bastion of progressive Republicanism until the realignment election of <a href="1992%20United%20States%20presidential%20election%20in%20Vermont">1992</a>, Vermont was the second most Democratic state in the nation, weighing in as a whopping 31.74% more Democratic than the national average in the 2012 election. Repeating his success from <a href="2008%20United%20States%20presidential%20election%20in%20Vermont">2008</a>, Obama again carried Vermont in a landslide, taking 66.57% of the vote to Romney's 30.97%, a Democratic victory margin of 35.60%. Though this was slightly worse than his 2008 performance, when he received 67.46% of the vote to Republican Senator <a href="John%20McCain">John McCain</a>'s 30.45%, a margin of 37.01%, this was still the second best performance for a Democrat in Vermont history, surpassing <a href="Lyndon%20B.%20Johnson">Lyndon B. Johnson</a>'s <a href="1964%20United%20States%20presidential%20election%20in%20Vermont">1964</a> performance.
Vermont historically was a bastion of northeastern Republicanism, voting Republican in every single election but one between <a href="1856%20United%20States%20presidential%20election%20in%20Vermont">1856</a> to <a href="1988%20United%20States%20presidential%20election%20in%20Vermont">1988</a>, interrupted only in <a href="1964%20United%20States%20presidential%20election%20in%20Vermont">1964</a>. It also elected solely Republican <a href="Governor%20of%20Vermont">governors</a> from 1854 to <a href="1962%20Vermont%20gubernatorial%20election">1962</a>. However, after migration from liberal northeastern cities such as <a href="Boston">Boston</a> and <a href="New%20York%20City">New York</a> to Vermont in the 1960s and 70s, it shifted sharply towards the Democratic Party with <a href="Bill%20Clinton">Bill Clinton</a>'s landslide victory in 1992, and has been part of the "<a href="Blue%20wall%20%28politics%29">Blue Wall</a>" – the 19 jurisdictions, worth 238 electoral votes, that voted Democratic six times in a row from 1992 through 2012 – ever since. Vermont also has one of the greenest economies in the country, with its own Clean Air Act and a state trust that buys farmland to support local farming. This, and a virtual nonexistence of party loyalty in the state, guaranteed Obama's landslide victory. The Green Mountain State's <a href="Constitution%20of%20Vermont">original constitution</a> <a href="Abolitionism">abolished</a> <a href="Slavery%20in%20the%20United%20States">slavery</a> and provided <a href="Universal%20manhood%20suffrage">universal male suffrage</a>, and the state government legalized <a href="Same-sex%20civil%20unions%20in%20the%20united%20states">same-sex civil unions</a> in July 2000, <a href="same-sex%20marriage">same-sex marriage</a> in 2009, and <a href="Decriminalization%20of%20non-medical%20cannabis%20in%20the%20United%20States">decriminalized</a> <a href="Cannabis%20%28drug%29">marijuana</a> in 2013.
Obama's best performance was in <a href="Windham%20County%2C%20Vermont">Windham County</a>, where he received 73.06% of the vote, though he also racked up great margins in <a href="Chittenden%20County%2C%20Vermont">Chittenden</a>, <a href="Rutland%20County%2C%20Vermont">Rutland</a>, and <a href="Washington%20County%2C%20Vermont">Washington Counties</a>, the state's three largest counties and home to Burlington, <a href="Rutland%20%28city%29%2C%20Vermont">Rutland</a>, and the state capital of <a href="Montpelier%2C%20Vermont">Montpelier</a>, respectively. The only county where he won by a margin of less than 20% is in <a href="Essex%20County%2C%20Vermont">Essex County</a> in the <a href="Northeast%20Kingdom">Northeast Kingdom</a>, generally the most conservative region in the state, where he won by 13.40%.
The results of the 2012 election made Vermont the second most Democratic state in the nation, only surpassed by the 42.71% margin in Obama's birth state of <a href="2012%20United%20States%20presidential%20election%20in%20Hawaii">Hawaii</a>.
As of 2020, this is the last election in which the Democrat won <a href="Essex%20County%2C%20Vermont">Essex County</a>, and by extension, every county in the state.
Democratic primary.
The Democratic primary took place on <a href="Super%20Tuesday">Super Tuesday</a>, March 6, 2012. <a href="Incumbent">Incumbent</a> <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President</a> <a href="Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama</a> ran unopposed. According to the <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20of%20Vermont">Secretary of State of Vermont</a>'s office, he received 40,247 votes (97.28%) and all of the 27 delegates attending the <a href="2012%20Democratic%20National%20Convention">2012 Democratic National Convention</a> in <a href="Charlotte%2C%20North%20Carolina">Charlotte, North Carolina</a> pledged to support his re-nomination. The remaining 2.72% of the vote was made up of 675 write-ins (1.63%) and 450 blank votes (1.09%).
Republican primary.
The Republican primary also took place on <a href="Super%20Tuesday">Super Tuesday</a>, March 6, 2012.
Vermont has 17 delegates to the <a href="2012%20Republican%20National%20Convention">2012 Republican National Convention</a>. Three <a href="superdelegate">superdelegate</a>s are bound by the primary results and awarded on a winner-take-all basis. The remaining 14 are awarded winner-take-all to the candidate who wins at least 50% of the vote statewide, or allocated proportionately among candidates winning at least 20% of the vote statewide if no one gets a majority.
Former <a href="Governor%20of%20Massachusetts">Massachusetts Governor</a> <a href="Mitt%20Romney">Mitt Romney</a> won the primary with a plurality, receiving 24,008 votes (39.45%) and 9 delegates. He won every single county. <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives">Representative</a> from <a href="Texas%27s%2014th%20congressional%20district">Texas's 14th district</a> <a href="Ron%20Paul">Ron Paul</a> placed in second with 15,391 votes, or 25.29%, while former <a href="United%20States%20Senate">Senator</a> from <a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a> <a href="Rick%20Santorum">Rick Santorum</a> received 14,368 votes, or 23.61%. Both were awarded 4 delegates. The only other candidate to receive over 5% of the vote was former <a href="Speaker%20of%20the%20United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives">Speaker of the House</a> <a href="Newt%20Gingrich">Newt Gingrich</a>, with 8.13% of the vote.
